scenario.description: Flight from Paris (CDG) to New York (JFK) delayed 4 hours due to mechanical issue. Airline claims weather was a factor but flight logs show mechanical problem as primary cause.

jurisdiction.reasoning: Flight departed from EU territory (France). EU Regulation 261/2004 applies to all flights departing from EU airports regardless of airline nationality or destination. French Civil Aviation Authority (DGAC) is enforcement body.
jurisdiction.notes: Confidence <1.0 because rare edge cases exist (diplomatic flights, military charters, aircraft under 20 passengers)

legalBasis.summary: Passengers are entitled to compensation of €250-€600 (depending on distance) when flights are delayed by 3+ hours at final destination, unless airline can prove extraordinary circumstances.
Defines 'extraordinary circumstances' as circumstances which could not have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken. Airlines have burden of proof.
For flights over 3,500 km between EU and third country, compensation is €600.

conditions.reasoning: CDG (Paris Charles de Gaulle) is definitively in EU territory (France). This is a factual matter with no ambiguity.

conditions.requirement: Delay at final destination was 3 hours or more
conditions.reasoning: Reported delay is 4 hours. Confidence <1.0 because we rely on passenger report; airline might dispute exact arrival time. EU regulation measures delay at final destination, not departure.
Paris to New York is approximately 5,837 km (great circle distance). This exceeds 3,500 km threshold for highest compensation tier.

conditions.requirement: Delay NOT caused by extraordinary circumstances
conditions.reasoning: Mechanical issues are generally NOT extraordinary circumstances per ECJ Case C-549/07. However, airline claims weather involvement. If weather was genuinely primary cause AND properly documented, this could qualify as extraordinary. Flight logs showing mechanical issue as primary cause strongly support passenger claim.
evidence: ECJ Case C-549/07: mechanical defects are inherent to aircraft operation, not extraordinary
Airline claim of weather not substantiated in logs
Weather must be sole/primary cause to exempt airline

conclusion.claim: You are likely entitled to €600 compensation under EU Regulation 261/2004. This is in addition to any reimbursement for meals, accommodation, or alternative transport the airline should have provided.

remedy.description: You are entitled to €600 compensation under EU Regulation 261/2004. This is in addition to any reimbursement for meals, accommodation, or alternative transport the airline should have provided.

uncertainties: Airline may present weather evidence we haven't seen that could lower confidence to ~0.40
Exact delay time might be disputed (arrival time definition varies slightly)
If airline proves weather was sole cause AND documented properly, entitlement drops to 0%
Mechanical issue classification could be challenged in edge cases (e.g., bird strike causing mechanical damage)

reasons: We don't have access to all airline documentation
Weather evidence might exist that exempts airline
Edge cases in regulation interpretation remain
Enforcement varies slightly between EU countries

prior.basis: Base rate: approximately 70% of EU delay claims over 3 hours result in compensation when mechanical issues are cited. This prior reflects general success rates before examining specific case details.
prior.source: AirHelp 2024 Claims Report; EU Commission 261/2004 Enforcement Statistics

evidence.reasoning: EU jurisdiction is clear and well-enforced. French DGAC has strong enforcement record. This substantially increases likelihood of successful claim.
Clear threshold met. Four hours is well above minimum, reducing disputes about exact timing. Minor uncertainty remains about precise arrival time measurement.
Distance clearly qualifies for maximum €600 tier. Paris-New York route is unambiguous. This slightly increases confidence (airlines less likely to dispute clear facts).

evidence.factor: Mechanical issue documented in flight logs
evidence.reasoning: Flight logs are strong evidence. ECJ precedent firmly establishes mechanical issues are not extraordinary. However, airline's weather claim creates some uncertainty.

Weather CAN be extraordinary circumstance if properly documented. This introduces uncertainty. However, flight logs show mechanical as primary cause, which limits impact of weather claim. Final confidence: 0.85.

howToChangeMyMind: Meteorological reports showing severe weather at CDG during departure window that grounded multiple flights → confidence drops to ~0.30
Evidence that other carriers successfully departed despite same mechanical issue → confidence increases to ~0.95
New ECJ ruling expanding definition of extraordinary circumstances → confidence could drop significantly
Airline produces no weather documentation → confidence increases to ~0.92

precedent.court: Court of Justice of the European Union
precedent.principle: Technical problems which come to light during maintenance of aircraft or on account of failure to carry out such maintenance cannot be regarded as 'extraordinary circumstances' under Article 5(3) of Regulation 261/2004. Airlines must maintain aircraft properly; mechanical failures are operational risks, not extraordinary circumstances.
precedent.relevance: Directly applicable. Establishes that mechanical issues do not exempt airlines from compensation obligations. This is foundational precedent for all EU mechanical delay cases.

precedent.court: Court of Justice of the European Union
precedent.principle: Only circumstances beyond airline's actual control can constitute extraordinary circumstances. Burden of proof rests entirely with airline to demonstrate both that circumstances were extraordinary AND that no reasonable measures could have prevented delay.
precedent.relevance: Clarifies burden of proof. Airline must affirmatively prove weather was cause, not merely assert it. Strengthens passenger position.

precedent.citation: Case C-159/18 Transportes Aéreos Portugueses v Vieira
precedent.court: Court of Justice of the European Union
precedent.principle: Bird strikes can constitute extraordinary circumstances IF airline proves all reasonable measures were taken and bird strike could not be avoided. However, subsequent mechanical failures from the strike are airline's responsibility.
precedent.relevance: Establishes that even when extraordinary event occurs (bird strike), resulting mechanical issues may still require compensation if airline could have mitigated. Relevant if airline claims extraordinary cause of mechanical issue.

enforcement.mechanism: File claim with airline within 2 years (France). If denied, escalate to national enforcement body (DGAC in France). Further escalation to Alternative Dispute Resolution or small claims court.
steps: 1. Gather documentation: boarding pass, delay confirmation, flight logs if available, any communication with airline
2. Submit written claim to Air France customer service within 2 years (6-week deadline for airline in France is guidance, 2 years is legal limit)
3. Clearly state: EU 261/2004 compensation claim, cite Article 7, request €600
4. Include: booking reference, flight number, date, delay duration, documented mechanical issue
5. Airline has 6 weeks to respond (French CAA guidance)
6. If denied or no response: file complaint with DGAC (Direction Générale de l'Aviation Civile)
8. If still unresolved: Alternative Dispute Resolution (Médiateur du Tourisme et du Voyage) or small claims court
9. Consider using claims services (AirHelp, ClaimCompass) - they take 25-35% commission but handle process
enforcement.successRateBasis: Based on 2023-2024 French DGAC enforcement statistics for mechanical delay claims over 3 hours on long-haul EU departures. Success rate reflects final compensation received after all levels of appeal.
enforcement.typicalTimeline: 2-6 months if airline accepts; 6-18 months if escalated to DGAC; up to 24 months if litigation required
enforcement.costToPassenger: €0 if DIY claim. Claims services charge 25-35% of compensation (€150-210 in this case). Small claims court filing fee approximately €35-75 in France.

realWorldFeedback.notes: Data from users who reported outcomes through this system. Not scientifically sampled but provides real-world validation.

bayesianUpdate.note: Real-world success rate (81.9%) closely matches our predicted confidence (85%), suggesting our Bayesian analysis is well-calibrated. No adjustment needed. Will continue monitoring as more data arrives.

learnings: Airlines challenge more aggressively when amount is €600 vs lower tiers
Documentation quality is critical - flight logs access makes huge difference
French DGAC responds within 8-12 weeks typically
Claims services (AirHelp, etc.) have 88% success rate, likely due to better documentation and legal expertise
